bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to W. Edwin Hemphill, October 26, 1951

div1.p: Hench writes that he enjoyed reading the article about Reed and refers to photographs that might be appropriate. Hench notes that he knows little of Reed's early life and refers Hemphill to Laura Wood's book.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to W. Edwin Hemphill, October 26, 1951
div1.opener:
October 26, 1951
Mr. W. Edwin Hemphill, Editor
VIRGINIA CAVALCADE
History Division
Virginia State Library
Richmond 19, Virginia
My dear Mr. Hemphill:
div1.p:
I have just returned a few days ago from two weeks absence to find a
letter either from you or one of your associates telling me about an
article on the early life of Walter Reed which you were planning to
publish in an early issue of the VIRGINIA CAVALCADE. I took the letter
home the other evening and spent a couple of hours looking over my files.
I was asked to suggest photographs. To make a long story short, I wrote
down on the letter a number of suggestions and now I simply cannot find
the letter. I do not recall whether the letter was from you or perhaps
from Mr. Randolph W. Church.

In any event, I shall be glad to help as I can. I enjoyed reading the
article but I must tell you that I have very little material which covers
the boyhood of Reed. I imagine that the author of the article consulted
Laura Wood's (Mrs. Laura Wood Roper) book on the life of Walter Reed.
This covers his boyhood more thoroughly than any book I know. I do have
in my possession the actual diploma which Reed obtained from the University
of Virginia giving him his first M.D. degree. If you want a photograph
of that I shall be glad to send one to you. Indeed I have all of Reed's
diplomas, presented to my collection by the Reed family. I have a couple
of photographs of Reed about the time of the yellow fever experiments
and I have an original of the conventional photograph of Reed. None of
these suit your purpose, I believe. There was published in 1926, I think
by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, a series of pamphlets called
“Health Heroes Series.” One of those pamphlets concerned Walter Reed.
About five or ten years ago they made a film on this article and illustrated
it with various photographs of Reed which I presume they obtained from the
Reed family. There is one of Reed at the age of about three or four years
I should judge; another of him at the age of 17; another about the age of
24 and then later photographs. Since this film, I believe, was copyrighted
by the insurance company, I could not send you my copies and give you per-
mission to use them. I have no doubt you could get permission from the
insurance company or get copies from the Reed family. It would be easier to
get copies from the insurance company.

I enclose a reprint by Dr. Arthur C. Jacobson. Please return it. My con-
tribution to this article was my letter which is published on pages 82 and 83.
This gives the reference to Laura Wood's book.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
Enclosure
Mr. W. Edwin Hemphill
- 2 -
P.S.: Since dictating the above I have found the letter and the manuscript.
The “Health Heroes” booklet was written by Grace T. Hallock and C. E. Turner.
You do not want the booklet but you may want permission to use the boyhood
pictures of Reed which the company used when they made the film on the matter.
It is not an ordinary movie but a large number of single frames on a con-
tinuous film (like a movie film) and used in a machine which projects each
frame separately.
I have pictures of the birthplace of Reed before and after it was fixed up.
I also have in my possession Reed's famous New Year's Eve letter to his wife,
New Year's 1900. I obtained from the National Archives a photograph of the
oath of office which Reed signed on December 23, 1893. The U. S. Army Medical
Museum has photographs of the bust of Reed: Ask for their negatives No.
71649 to 61751.
I think it would be nice to use a photograph of the Academy in Charlottesville
where Reed went to school, also the house in Charlottesville where he lived
with his family. My brother, at the University of Virginia, tells me that
the house has been located and it is marked I believe.
One point about the manuscript. On page 5 your writer says that Reed replied
“Gentlemen, I will hold you to your promise.” Somehow I just can't swallow
that. I can't imagine a 16 year old boy rather pompously challenging the faculty
representative in that manner. This alleged quotation of Reed's, to me seems
to be in a class with an even more famous supposed quotation which he is sup-
possed to have made when Kissinger and Moran volunteered their services to
him for the mosquito bites. Reed is supposed to have risen, saluted them and
said “Gentlemen, I salute you.” I just don't think Reed was given to such
heroics and as for the latter quotation, even though Kelly gives it in his
book and it has been widely quoted, it is quite untrue. Actually Kissinger
and Moran went to Reed separately and they have both told me most emphatically
that no such remark was made to either. I would regard both of these quota-
tions as candidates for that column which occasionally appears in The New
Yorker Magazine, “Quotations which We Believe Never Got Quoted.”
May I keep the manuscript? I assume it is merely a copy.
